level.text: Violation of any of the following provisions shall be a Class 1 infraction:

Section 4 of An Act To create a board for the condemnation of insanitary buildings in the District of Columbia, approved May 1, 1906 (34 Stat. 158, ch. 2073; D.C. Official Code § 6-904) (permitting the occupancy of a condemned building without authorization by the Board for the Condemnation of Insanitary Buildings);

Section 5 of an Act To create a board for the condemnation of insanitary buildings in the District of Columbia (D.C. Official Code § 6-905) (failure to obtain any required permit when work is undertaken to repair, make habitable or demolish a condemned building.); or

Section 12 of An Act To create a board for the condemnation of insanitary buildings in the District of Columbia (D.C. Official Code § 6-912) (defacing, removing or concealing any copy of any order of condemnation which has been affixed to any condemned building).
Violation of any of the following provisions shall be a Class 2 infraction:

Section 11 of An Act To create a board for the condemnation of insanitary buildings in the District of Columbia (D.C. Official Code § 6-911) (hindering, preventing or refusing to permit a lawful inspection of the premises.);

Section 3 of An Act To create a board for the condemnation of insanitary buildings in the District of Columbia (D.C. Official Code § 6-903) (failure to show cause within the time specified why such building or part of building should not be condemned);

Section 7 of An Act To create a board for the condemnation of insanitary buildings in the District of Columbia (D.C. Official Code § 6-907) (failure of the owner to cause such building to be put into a habitable and sanitary condition or to be demolished and removed within the time specified by the Board in the order of condemnation); or

Section 15 of an Act To create a board for the condemnation of insanitary buildings in the District of Columbia (D.C. Official Code § 6-915) (tenants or occupants neglecting or causing to exist unsanitary conditions which have led to the condemnation of a building.
